This should ensure  that the following stylesheet processing instruction is honored by  these new browser versions. For some more background you might want  to visit the following bug report:  https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=338621  --> <?xml-stylesheet type="text/xsl" href="/WebResource.axd?d=OG6ICBS3XdykvyL_wBngEtwfPZ1xqVL3SJbFznhjfEgbO7QCYjHbDfgdgnO_5IYl31FcIeZ2u_qHqs8zCgU_y6DDpKxLyAV4MxNJVxfxbqAA9wnJHfwytgbvEYfRnFp2CKySbJEfaqzaXNpSNK6oTGhGshY1&t=635319500310794128" media="screen"?> <feed xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom" xmlns:content="http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/content/" xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/">   <title>Classics</title>   <subtitle>At the Department of Classics at Nottingham, we teach and research all aspects of the cultures of ancient Greece and Rome \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd  Greek and Latin language as well as Greek and Roman literature, history, art and life. The fascination of the classical world lies in the richness of its culture and in the fact that we have direct access to it through surviving works of Greek and Roman writers, monuments, art and archaeological evidence.</subtitle>   <link href="http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/classics/classics.aspx?RelatedItemsasStandardList_SyndicationType=2" />   <generator>Contensis: http://www.contentmanagement.co.uk</generator>   <id>http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/classics/classics.aspx?SyndicationType=2</id>   <updated>2015-03-06T08:19:08Z</updated>   <link href="http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/classics/classics.aspx?SyndicationType=2" rel="self" type="application/atom+xml" />   <entry>     <title>Ancient History BA</title>     <link href="http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/classics/ancient-history.aspx" />     <author>       <name>Nicola Caseldine</name>     </author>     <summary>This course examines the political, social, economic and cultural history of ancient Greece and Rome. It does not merely handle facts and events, but what lies behind them and what makes them significant and exciting: progress and decline, labour and leisure, revolution and reconciliation, conquest, exploitation and resistance.</summary>     <published>2011-07-13T17:34:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-02-26T15:13:00Z</updated>     <id>http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/classics/ancient-history.aspx</id>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Classics BA</title>     <link href="http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/classics/classics-ba.aspx" />     <author>       <name>Nicola Caseldine</name>     </author>     <summary>This course offers the opportunity to study both Greek and Latin language at an advanced level. As well as reading some of the greatest achievements in Western literature, from Homer to Lucian, Horace to Apuleius and engaging with these texts in the complexity and richness of their original form, you will use your language skills to think about the ancient world, its culture and history.</summary>     <published>2011-07-13T17:34:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-02-26T15:21:00Z</updated>     <id>http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/classics/classics-ba.aspx</id>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Classical Civilisation BA</title>     <link href="http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/classics/classical-civilisation.aspx" />     <author>       <name>Nicola Caseldine</name>     </author>     <summary>This course examines the literature, culture and society of classical Greece and Rome. You will also be able to study political and social structures, art and visual culture, thought, religion and social life. No prior knowledge of Greek or Latin or classical civilisation is required and, except in designated language courses, all texts are read in translation.</summary>     <published>2011-07-13T17:34:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-02-26T15:25:00Z</updated>     <id>http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/classics/classical-civilisation.aspx</id>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Latin BA</title>     <link href="http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/classics/latin.aspx" />     <author>       <name>Rose Stapleton</name>     </author>     <summary>This course combines the learning of Latin to a high level of proficiency with the wider study of a range of aspects of classical history, society and culture. It is particularly suited to those of you who wish to specialise in Latin but don't want to learn Greek. You will study Latin language and literature in all three years.</summary>     <published>2011-07-13T17:35:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-03-05T09:58:00Z</updated>     <id>http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/classics/latin.aspx</id>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Ancient History and Archaeology BA</title>     <link href="http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/classics/ancient-history-archaeology.aspx" />     <author>       <name>Rose Stapleton</name>     </author>     <summary>This course emphasises both the common ground between ancient history and archaeology and the different approaches of the two disciplines. It is suited to those who wish to approach an understanding of the ancient world through both the material, literary and documentary evidence.</summary>     <published>2011-07-13T17:34:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-03-05T10:09:00Z</updated>     <id>http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/classics/ancient-history-archaeology.aspx</id>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Archaeology and Classical Civilisation BA</title>     <link href="http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/classics/archaeology-classical-civilisation.aspx" />     <author>       <name>Rose Stapleton</name>     </author>     <summary>This course offers the opportunity to combine a broad engagement with classical culture and society with learning archaeological skills and techniques, to enable first-hand study of material culture.</summary>     <published>2011-07-13T17:34:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-03-05T10:10:00Z</updated>     <id>http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/classics/archaeology-classical-civilisation.aspx</id>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Classical Civilisation and Philosophy BA</title>     <link href="http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/philosophy/classical-civilisation-philosophy.aspx" />     <author>       <name>Monica Beale</name>     </author>     <summary>This course combines the study of the classical world with a rigorous training in analytical philosophy. You will have the opportunity to study classical history, art and visual culture, thought, religion and social life as well as some key thinkers, ideas, and movements that have shaped philosophical thought.</summary>     <published>2011-07-13T17:54:00Z</published>     <updated>2014-11-17T16:30:00Z</updated>     <id>http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/philosophy/classical-civilisation-philosophy.aspx</id>   </entry> </feed>
